awd_titl_txt: INFEWS/T1: Understanding multi-scale resilience options for vulnerable regions
awd_abstract_narration:
The world is undergoing an energy revolution. Centralized electricity production and grid connections are multiplying electricity access for cities and industry in emerging economies worldwide, while distributed renewable technologies offer opportunities for communities beyond the grid. These changes are transforming societies and they have diverse impacts on food systems, and ultimately food security, on scales from household to global. At the same time, climate change has the potential to impose both local and global hydrological shocks that affect food and energy systems at multiple levels. Who will benefit from this rapidly changing food, energy, and climate landscape, and who might be left behind? How will technological, investment and policy strategies shape these outcomes? And how might external shocks, arising from global market dynamics and large-scale climate change, alter the course of energy and food security development? The answers to these questions are critical to development in emerging economies and, potentially, to social stability within and beyond their borders. To understand and predict these dynamics, the research team supported by this award will construct a systems-based modeling framework that captures local-scale to national-scale food, energy, and water dynamics in a changing climate. The framework will be implemented for Ethiopia and Mali, two rapidly developing but highly climate vulnerable countries that serve as test cases for a more generalizable analysis system. United States researchers will work with African counterparts and development experts to develop modeling tools and apply them to active and proposed energy and food security initiatives.

The ultimate objective of this work is to understand coupled system dynamics across scales in a manner that allows one to quantify the sensitivity of critical human outcomes (nutritional satisfaction, household economic well-being) to development and climate adaptation strategies. The research team will approach this problem with an integrated Multi-scale Energy and Food Systems (MEFS) modeling framework that includes a local "agent-based model" to capture individual behavior and learning; a scalable multi-player "micro-economic partial-equilibrium model" to simulate area-aggregated decisions and outcomes,;and a national computable "general equilibrium model" to simulate large-scale policy dynamics. MEFS couples the three models, which makes it possible to study the role that individual behavior and learning plays in area-aggregated decisions and to quantify the cross-scale impacts of bottom-up and top-down development interventions, such as household-level solar energy versus national energy subsidies. MEFS will provide novel insights on food-energy-water dynamics in the sub-Saharan Africa context, while the novel coupling methods developed for MEFS will advance the science of multi-scale systems modeling for research anywhere. The project also includes a significant educational component in which United States graduate students participate in collaborative research and training with graduate students at multiple African universities.

por.por_cntn:
This project was concerned with the propagation of climate shocks through human systems: across scales, over time, and through interacting dynamics of food, energy and water systems. We aimed to build a predictive understanding of how these shocks propagate. To do this, we worked with partners in two climate vulnerable countries (Ethiopia and Mali) to characterize vulnerabilities and opportunities for climate resilience in the food, energy, and water sectors, and to identify case studies and data sources that could be used to quantify stresses, interactions, and outcomes. We then worked to build natural and human systems models that simulate the impacts of climate shocks, and that can be applied to study the potential for specific policies and technologies to buffer against these impacts.

For example, under conditions of drought-induced food insecurity, one could consider investing in direct cash aid to vulnerable populations, subsidizing production, enhancing food trade flows, or other policies. Using a combination of climate, crop, and economic market models we conclude that for an acute (one year) crop failure affecting one part of a food insecure country, direct cash aid to the most vulnerable has the most immediate benefit for nutritional outcomes, while investment in trade flows can improve food security over time?but only if complementary policies are implemented to protect the poorest in both the affected region and neighboring regions that feel the climate shock via its propagation through food markets. Another example of an intervention to support food and water security during drought is the distribution of solar-powered pumps for groundwater-based irrigation. To understand the potential of this intervention, we coupled satellite-informed hydrological models to crop models and a food trade model. We found that during a major drought, access to this distributed energy technology provided significant benefit for crop producers, but that complementary policies would be necessary to ensure that enhanced production led to an increase in affordable food for the landless. We also found that the technology led to groundwater depletion that would have to be managed over longer time periods. The project used similar sets of tools to study a number of other climate-related challenges to the food-energy-water nexus, including reservoir management to meet competing objectives of hydropower generation, flood control, and crop irrigation, expansion of the national electricity grid to support both industrial growth and rural electrification, the influence of distributed bioenergy production (in the form of eucalyptus plantations) on food, energy, and water security, and the implications of changing patterns of climate variability for agricultural production and food prices.

In addition to addressing fundamental questions about shocks across coupled, multisector systems, the project included a significant policy outreach component. We held workshops and targeted discussions with government officials in Ethiopia and Mali in order to understand priorities and constraints for climate adaptation in both countries, and we have also brought project results to partners working with USAID, the World Bank, the United Nations Development Programme, and the Gates Foundation. Another highlight of the project was our opportunity to bring graduate students from the United States to Ethiopia to work directly with counterpart Ethiopian students. This place-based research experience led to collaborations that yielded publications jointly authored by United States and Ethiopian students, and that enriched the research and professional development of numerous U.S. graduate students.

Overall, work performed under this project contributed to our ability to study and predict the dynamics of propagating shocks in climate-vulnerable settings. Results highlight the potential for maladaptation when cross-scale or cross-sector dynamics are not considered?for example, if national energy development priorities do not account for localized impacts on food security. Results also highlight opportunities to advance climate resilience by considering holistic opportunities rather than focusing on specific challenges isolation: sometimes the answer to a local problem is also local, but sometimes we can build resilience by leveraging the propagation of shocks and policy responses across scale, sectors, geography, and communities.
